verses.text: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
verses.comment: God speaks to Job through a storm, echoing the divine presence revealed through natural phenomena elsewhere in Scripture.

verses.text: Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?
verses.comment: The LORD confronts Job’s limited understanding, preparing him for a lesson in divine wisdom.

verses.text: Brace yourself like a man; I will question you, and you shall answer me.
verses.comment: God calls Job to respond as one called to account—foreshadowing the prophetic and apostolic commission to witness and defend the faith.

verses.text: Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth? Tell me, if you have understanding.
verses.comment: God’s creative act mirrors the Genesis account, emphasizing His sovereignty and humanity’s limited perspective.

verses.text: Who determined its measurements—surely you know! Or who stretched the line upon it?
verses.comment: God’s wisdom as architect is echoed in Proverbs, where Wisdom is personified. This prefigures Christ as the Logos.

verses.text: On what were its bases sunk, or who laid its cornerstone,
verses.comment: The idea of a 'cornerstone' is fulfilled in Christ (cf. Eph. 2:20), who is the foundation of the new covenant community.

verses.text: when the morning stars sang together and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
verses.comment: The 'sons of God' refer to angelic beings. The imagery foreshadows heavenly rejoicing at Christ's birth.

verses.text: Or who shut in the sea with doors when it burst out from the womb,
verses.comment: God controls the sea, a symbol of chaos, emphasizing His authority over creation—seen also when Christ calms the storm (Matt. 8:26).

verses.text: when I made clouds its garment and thick darkness its swaddling band,
verses.comment: The poetic imagery underscores God’s fatherly care and sustaining providence over the world.

verses.text: and prescribed limits for it and set bars and doors,
verses.comment: God establishes order out of chaos, drawing boundaries in creation—pointing forward to spiritual boundaries in the life of faith.

verses.text: and said, ‘This far you shall come, and no farther; here shall your proud waves be stopped’?
verses.comment: God’s absolute authority over the sea represents His control even over evil and suffering.

verses.text: Have you commanded the morning since your days began, and caused the dawn to know its place,
verses.comment: God governs time and light, reflecting Christ as the 'Light of the World' (John 8:12).

verses.text: that it might take hold of the edges of the earth, and the wicked be shaken out of it?
verses.comment: God’s justice and sovereignty actively work to expose and restrain evil—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s kingdom.

verses.text: It is changed like clay under the seal, and its features stand out like a garment.
verses.comment: The metaphor evokes human craftsmanship, showing God as potter—a familiar biblical image (cf. Rom. 9:21).

verses.text: From the wicked their light is withheld, and their uplifted arm is broken.
verses.comment: God’s righteous judgment restrains the power of the wicked for the sake of the righteous.

verses.text: Have you entered into the springs of the sea, or walked in the recesses of the deep?
verses.comment: God reveals mysteries of creation hidden from human understanding, pointing to divine transcendence.

verses.text: Have the gates of death been revealed to you, or have you seen the gates of deep darkness?
verses.comment: The language anticipates Christ’s victory over death and His authority over Hades (cf. Rev. 1:18).

verses.text: Have you comprehended the expanse of the earth? Declare, if you know all this.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience and omnipresence are stressed, contrasting with human finitude.

verses.text: Where is the way to the dwelling of light, and darkness, where is its place,
verses.comment: Echoes the mystery of Christ as the true Light coming into the world, defeating darkness by His presence.

verses.text: that you may take it to its territory and discern the paths to its home?
verses.comment: Invites contemplation of creation’s mysteries, prompting humility and awe before God’s wisdom.

verses.text: You know, for you were born then, and the number of your days is great!
verses.comment: God’s irony exposes human presumption versus divine eternity.

verses.text: Have you entered the storehouses of the snow, or have you seen the storehouses of the hail,
verses.comment: God’s control over the weather signals divine providence and sovereignty.

verses.text: which I have reserved for the time of trouble, for the day of battle and war?
verses.comment: God is Lord over history, using nature as instrument for justice—a theme carried into the New Testament’s apocalyptic visions.

verses.text: What is the way to the place where the light is distributed, or where the east wind is scattered upon the earth?
verses.comment: God governs the forces of nature, again inviting humility before His power.

verses.text: Who has cut a channel for the torrents of rain, and a way for the thunderbolt,
verses.comment: Reflects God’s ongoing governance, prefiguring sacramental signs of grace—where physical means convey spiritual realities.

verses.text: to bring rain on a land where no man is, on the desert in which there is no man,
verses.comment: God’s care extends even to the uninhabited places, symbolizing grace poured out even where it is unseen.

verses.text: to satisfy the waste and desolate land, and to make the ground sprout with grass?
verses.comment: The language suggests a spiritual renewal, as God brings life where there was barrenness.

verses.text: Has the rain a father, or who has begotten the drops of dew?
verses.comment: God alone is the source of all blessings, both natural and supernatural.

verses.text: From whose womb did the ice come forth, and who has given birth to the frost of heaven?
verses.comment: Every detail in creation is under God’s providence, a sign of His intimate involvement in the world.

verses.text: The waters become hard like stone, and the surface of the deep is frozen.
verses.comment: God’s power over the elements recalls miracles involving water in both Testaments.

verses.text: Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades or loosen the cords of Orion?
verses.comment: God’s mastery over the stars points to His greater order and design—a motif used in Scripture for divine rule.

verses.text: Can you lead forth the Mazzaroth in their season, or guide the Bear with its children?
verses.comment: Mazzaroth refers to constellations or heavenly bodies, which God alone directs.

verses.text: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you establish their rule on the earth?
verses.comment: All the laws of nature reflect the order God has set—hinting at the spiritual law He reveals through revelation.

verses.text: Can you lift up your voice to the clouds, that a flood of waters may cover you?
verses.comment: God hears and responds to prayer, but does so as sovereign Lord, pointing to the necessity of humility before Him.

verses.text: Can you send forth lightning, that they may go and say to you, ‘Here we are’?
verses.comment: God’s command even over lightning demonstrates His direct involvement—anticipating miraculous signs in salvation history.

verses.text: Who has put wisdom in the inward parts or given understanding to the mind?
verses.comment: God imparts wisdom, both naturally and in the interior life—a spiritual gift accessible through grace.

verses.text: Who can number the clouds by wisdom? Or who can tilt the waterskins of the heavens,
verses.comment: Again, the abundance of rainfall points to God’s blessings, prefiguring outpourings of the Spirit.

verses.text: when the dust hardens into a mass and the clods stick together?
verses.comment: The formation of the earth recalls God creating Adam from the ground, affirming the unity of material and spiritual creation.

verses.text: Can you hunt prey for the lion, or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
verses.comment: God provides for all creatures, indicating His providence extends to every corner of creation.

verses.text: when they crouch in their dens or lie in wait in their thicket?
verses.comment: As a shepherd cares for his sheep, God provides for every living creature.

verses.text: Who provides for the raven its food, when its young ones cry to God for help and wander about without food?
verses.comment: Jesus later refers to God feeding the ravens to illustrate confidence in divine providence. God’s intimate concern for all creation invites total trust in His plan—both for daily needs and spiritual nourishment.
